questions.text: Which of the following formulates food standards for the international food market?
questions.solution:
The Codex Alimentarius Commission formulates food standards for the international market. It is the principal organ of the FAO/WHO food standards program.

The ISI standards (Indian Standards Institute) and AGMARK are the Indian food standards. They are based on the standards of Codex Alimentarius.

The PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) Act was introduced to provide protection from adulteration or contamination of food.

questions.text: What is the dose of vitamin A added during fortification of vanaspati?
questions.solution:
Vanaspati is fortified with 2500 IU of vitamin A and 175 IU of vitamin D.

Note: 1g of double fortified salt contains 40 mcg iodine and 1 mg iron.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to a significant loss  of beta carotene from food?
questions.solution:
Dehydration contributes to a significant loss in the beta carotene levels in food.

Processes that do not affect beta carotene levels in the food are:

  • Boiling
  • Canning
  • Freezing

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.

The iodization of salt is used as a prophylactic measure against endemic goiter. In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act.

questions.text: In a milk factory, the milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes and then cooled quickly to less than 13°C . Which bacteria can survive this method?
questions.solution:
The method described above is the holder method of pasteurization. Coxiella burnetti can survive this method since it is highly heat-resistant. It causes Q fever.

The various methods of pasteurization are:

  • Holder/Vat method - 63-66 °C for 30 minutes
  • HTST method (high-temperature short time) - 72°C for 15 seconds
  • UHT method (ultra-high temperature) - 125 °C for a few seconds

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to check the efficiency of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
Methylene blue reduction test is not used to check the efficiency of pasteurization. This test is used for grading raw milk quality prior to pasteurization.

The following tests are used to check the efficiency of pasteurization:

  • Phosphatase test
  • Standard plate count
  • Coliform count

questions.text: In a rice processing factory, paddy is soaked in hot water.  After this, the water is drained and the paddy is steamed and dried. Which of the following statements is false about the above process?

choices.text: This method is used for partial cooking of rice
It makes the rice grains resistant to insects
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm during this process

questions.solution:
The procedure mentioned above is parboiling. It hardens the rice grains.

Parboiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam. It is done by the hot soaking process that was initially developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

The advantages of parboiling are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality by driving the vitamins and minerals into the endosperm.
  • Hardens the grains and makes them insect resistant.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with gradually progressive muscle weakness and leg spasms for 2 months. He says that he had been consuming an inexpensive dal resembling red gram for the past 2 years. Pure motor paresis was seen on examination. Which of the following could have prevented this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of neurolathyrism. It can be prevented and treated by the administration of vitamin C at doses of 500-1000 mg.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram.

BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being evaluated for sudden onset of hypersecretory glaucoma, diarrhea, and cardiac failure. Further probing reveals that she had been purchasing groceries from a dealer who was recently arrested for food adulteration. What toxin is likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test
